Explanations about Options.-d(M): Remove (delete) entries from a zip archive. For example:
Explanations about Options.-j(M):
Store just the name of a saved file (junk the path), and do not store directory
 names. By default, zip will store the full path (relative to the current
 directory).

Explanations about Options.-p(M):
extract files to pipe (stdout). Nothing but the file data is sent to stdout , and
 the files are always extracted in binary format, just as they are stored (no
 conversions).
Explanations about Options.-q(M):
perform operations quietly (-qq = even quieter). Ordinarily unzip prints the names
 of the files it's extracting or testing, the extraction methods, any file or
 zipfile comments that may be stored in the archive, and possibly a summary when
 finished with each archive. The -q[q] options suppress the printing of some or all
 of these messages.

Answers.MP Summary: list, test and extract compressed files in a ZIP archive
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: List the contents of a zip file without extracting
Top-3 Scripts:
su_550837: unzip -lqq file.zip | gawk -F"  " '{print $NF;}' |
  while IFS= read -r n; do rm "$n"; done

unzip -lqq file.zip | gawk -F"  " '{print $NF;}' |
  while IFS= read -r n; do rm "$n"; done; rmdir *

unzip -lqq file.zip | gawk -F"  " '{print $NF;}' |
  while IFS= read -r n; do rm -ri "$n"; done; rmdir *

unzip -lqq file.zip | gawk -F"  " '{print $NF;}' |
  while IFS= read -r n; do rm -rf "$n"; done

Explanations about Options.--transform(M): Use sed replace EXPRESSION to transform file names.
Explanations about Options.-c(C): I zipped 6 files (total size = 2gb) using "gzip -c myfiles_* > ~/myzip.gzip" and got my friend to copy this server to another server. So you'd "tar cvf - ./path_to_tar | gzip -c > file.tar.gz".
Explanations about Options.-c(M):
Create a new archive. Arguments supply the names of the files to be archived.
 Directories are archived recursively, unless the --no-recursion option is given.
Explanations about Options.-x(M):
Extract files from an archive. Arguments are optional. When given, they specify
 names of the archive members to be extracted.

Explanations about Options.-d(C): Use "unzip $1 -d "${target}"" if you want to extract the archive to a directory alongside it instead.
Explanations about Options.-d(M):
Always create a containing directory for the contents of the unpacked archive. By
 default, a directory is created if there is more than one top-level file or folder.
